newsitem.title: USA: US SEC alleges insider trading in APL Ltd.
newsitem.headline: US SEC alleges insider trading in APL Ltd.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday it filed insider trading charges against a Singapore man and one other unknown party, involving call option trades in APL Ltd that took place last week.

The agency alleged that Ong Congqin Bobby and the unknown party bought call options in APL on April 11, prior to the company's public announcement on April 13 that it would be acquired by Singapore-based Neptune Orient Lines Ltd for $825 million.
The agency said the unknown party bought a total of 400 APL May call options and 400 APL July call options anonymously through an account maintained by Dresdner Bank AG.
Ong Congqin Bobby was accused by the agency of buying 340 May 20 APL call options and 550 May APL options through a newly-opened trading account at Prudential-Bache Securities Asia Pacific Ltd.
The SEC said the two sets of purchases represented 74 percent of trading volume in these option series that day.
On Monday, the day after the announcement, the price of APL stock increased by $8.25 a share, closing at $29.75, or 38 percent higher than the $21.50 closing price the previous Friday, the SEC said.
The SEC said it is seeking civil penalties and forfeiture of the alleged illegal trading profits. The court has granted the agency's request for an order temporarily freezing the assets.
A preliminary injunction hearing is scheduled for April 25.
APL, with headquarters in Oakland, Calif. provides ocean-going cargo transportation services primarily in the trans-Pacific market.
